English: Kolguyev, 1987
You can go!
Go, Soviet!
We're done here. Let's go!
Welcome back to the Soviet Union, comrade Grigory Lemontov. You have been kept from your home country for far too long.
Your unlawful imprisonment by the capitalists of the west has finally come to an end.\nWe are honoured to be able to welcome you back.
Three cheers for the return of Grigory Lemontov to his motherland!
Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!
It's... good to be back, comrades. Thank you.
Long live comrade Lemontov! Hurrah!
If you would, please, follow me to my car, comrade. I'll take you to your tent.
Welcome back, comrade Lemontov. My name is Stanislav Shaposhnikov and I was responsible for the exchange.
Those three were western spies captured in Moscow. We reached a deal wherein you would be exchanged for them.
Where are we going?
To Severovodsk. You'll have your accommodations there.
Back there, it felt like you were welcoming a hero.
But we were, weren't we? To those that remember you, you are a great commander. To those new, you are a legend.
Hm, I don't feel like either. Isn't that Arzapol? Did nobody bother to repair any of the destroyed buildings?
We never received the budget. And honestly, it reminds men of our defeat and motivates them to get better.
I was gone for seven years and Kolguyev still looks exactly the same.
The island itself has not changed. Other things have. You'll see that soon enough for yourself.
Stanislav Shaposhnikov... the name rings a bell, we must have met. Were you under Livanokh?
You could say that. I was under Rashiv.
Vadim Rashiv? Wait, I remember you...
Comrade Lemontov, let us not discuss it here. We shall talk in Severovodsk.
We're here. Follow me.
This tent has been assigned to you. Mine is just around the corner. We can talk freely here.
I rememeber you. How did you survive?
Those blokes you left me with wanted to hang me from a tree.\nBefore they could agree on which one, an American commando showed up and captured us.
I spent the rest of the war imprisoned.
The fate of my comrades and Rashiv I only learned later. Nobody else from my group survived.\nYou made sure of that.
Trust me, not a day goes by that I don't regret what I did.
Remorse is a common feeling for those sentenced behind bars. It does not wash away your guilt, however.
I'm not asking for forgiveness. At the time, I did what I perceived as right, as necessary for the better of my country, my people.\nI was wrong, but I can't take it back.
I won't judge you for your past actions, I leave that to God. I already came to terms with what occurred.\nIt is nothing we can change, unlike the future.
After the war I learned about the Americans raiding the villa and capturing you while killing Livanokh.\nThat's the official version of events.
Most people don't have a reason not to believe it, but I'm not among them.\nI met with George Dyaconsen and he was not the kind of man to shoot first and ask questions later.
What are you implying?
You were Livanokh's loyal dog.\nIf there was a fatality during the raid, it would have been you, as you would defend him to the last breath, am I not right?
Spit it out. What do you think happened?
Do you really wish me to say it aloud? I think you killed Livanokh.
And if I did, what does it make me?
A hero, of course. That's what I would tell you. Livanokh had to be stopped.\nIf you ever wondered whether you've done the right thing, you have.
Unfortunately, that is not the generally accepted opinion among our comrades.\nYou should know that the Army general in charge of Kolguyev is Vladimir Volkov.
I remember him. A low ranking officer, dutiful and efficient.
Well, he climbed high and now controls Kolguyev and wields substantial political influence.\nNot enough to cause trouble yet, but enough to be of concern.
What is his plan?
I'm not sure, I only know he is still loyal to Livanokh and what was he trying to achieve. He might be continuing in his legacy.
I did not stop one madman to let another finish his job. Does he possess nuclear weapons?
Not yet, thank god. But you do know the significance of Malden and what could that mean.
Does he wish to invade?
I don't know. It seems like it, as we are concentrating more and more forces on Kolguyev. Slowly still, but surely.
What's the situation back home?
Not good. A general political instability and corruption, seceding states, economic recession, the whole mess that is Afghanistan...
It's much different than what you remember.
This does sound serious. Can I count on you?
It is strange to hear you say that, Lemontov, but yes. I'll never forget what you did to Rashiv, but this is what he was fighting against.\nHe would want us to finish the fight.
Good, thank you. First and foremost, I need information. I have seven year long window I need to fill.
I also need to meet the local commanders and get to know them to get a bigger picture of the situation.
Yes, you're right. Volkov is coming in tomorrow and will want to see you.\nHe ordered a uniform to be made for you, so it seems he wants you back in the army.
Then I am safe as long as I keep the truth secret. It might come out one day, so I must be ready for that.\nUntil then, we can work with the time we have.
What do you think would happen were they to find out?
Not sure, but if Volkov's anything like my old self, I'll get probably shot without much parade. It's better not to test it.
Absolutely. Now, let's see... there are five important people you should meet.
First, you need to meet Zubarev, the commander-in-chief. He is in charge when Volkov is not here.
He is more of a politician than a soldier and I have my doubts about his military capabilities, but he's very close to Volkov.\nBe mindful around him.
Second, there's Kaplinsky, the commander of spetsnaz. You'll probably have to spend a lot of time with him very soon.\nI don't know much about him.
Third, Frolov, the tank commander, you are already familiar with him. He hasn't changed much since your time.
Fourth, the newcomer, Syomin. From what I've heard, a brilliant ace pilot and the commander of the air force.
Apparently, he has a family history of piloting. Don't let him start talking about that, you'll never hear the end of it.
Fifth, the logistics officer, Chernikov. He can be hard to find, just keep looking. He is in charge of all supplies.
Additionally, If you wish to hear more about the events you missed, I can recommend two other people.
For domestic politics and the general world affairs, you can go to the postmaster, Boris Belsky.\nEvery piece of paper, fax or telegram goes through him.
He is also able to get his hands on some foreign journals,\nso he knows a lot about the wider world.
Concerning the archipelago, you should go to Maksim Kuznetsov. Supposedly, he's been here from the very beginning.
He's from logistics and knows everyone in the army. A good man to meet regardless.
You can take my car if you wish. Once you are done, get back to me. I'll be in my tent waiting for you.
Alright, see you later.
Grigory Lemontov in the flesh. I almost didn't believe it when they said you'd be coming back.
Comrade Zubarev I presume?
You presume right. You should know I was against the exchange. We lost three valuable spies.
It's one way to look at it.
I don't really see any benefit you are supposed to bring us.
I suppose, while you're here, you could at the very least tell me about Livanokh.\nYou were there with him during the final moments, weren't you?
I would rather tell that personally to comrade Volkov, when he arrives.
Yes, of course, he should be the first to know. Tell me about the prison then.
It was long and solitary. Nothing of any interest.
What about the enemy? Any information or news?
No.
You haven't seen anything or heard anything?
Comrade Zubarev, I was in prison.
Yes, I see. Never mind. Have you talked with Kaplinsky yet?
I have.
Good, then you know you shall be leading spetsnaz again.
It didn't sound like I was given a choice.
What would you possibly do instead? Get back to the mainland to lead a civil life?
Not yet.
You should. He has information regarding your future in the army.
Do you mean I cannot just pack my things and go back to the mainland to lead a civil life?
Don't be ridiculous. I've read your files. You've been soldier your whole life.
Don't you feel any resentment to the Americans?\nThey killed your brother Livanokh before your eyes. Or did the prison time break your will?
It's been ten years since I've been back in Russia, comrade Zubarev. That is all.
You shall return, comrade Lemontov, do not worry about that.\nBut there is still work to be done before that can happen.
That's something we can agree on.
Can you tell me something about yourself?

Zubarev is a name you should be familiar with.\nI come from a family with a long military tradition.\nOne of my forefathers commanded a batallion on the right wing in the battle of Borodino, during Napoleonic wars.
Impressive.
During the revolution, my grandfather helped comrade Stalin in the capture of Tsaritsyn.\nHe was commended for his actions by comrade Stalin himself. As you can see, military is my second nature.
What is the first?
I am well versed in politics.\nI am the second advisor to the Minister of Defence. I offer counsel on other matters as well.
I have to travel a lot between Kolguyev and Moscow to fulfill my many duties,\nbut that is the fate of those skilled and needed.
What's the army situation like?
The peace treaty forbids us to station too many men on the island.\nWe do what we can with the little we have.
Our office corps is experienced and we have many new recruits.\nKolguyev serves as a training centre at the moment more than a garrison.

Our other duty is to monitor the situation in the archipelago.\nAfter all, we are the closest military personnel to the enemy after the city of Berlin.\nAny information we can gather is invaluable back home.
Interesting discussion, comrade. I'll be heading out.
Go, we'll be seeing each other plenty of times.\nAnd maybe once you get back into shape you might become useful.
I can't wait to work with you, comrade Zubarev. Goodbye.
I'll be watching you, Lemontov.
What is it, comrade?
Comrade Grigory Lemontov, it is very good to finally meet you.\nWe never had the pleasure - Valentin Syomin, commander of the air force.
We had not. The pleasure is all mine.
Your imprisonment was very unfortunate. I've heard of your deeds and I am glad you are able to join us again.\nHow is your health?
It was boring and solitary, comrade Syomin, but I wasn't tortured.\nI am as healthy as one can be.
No food deprivation, beatings or waterboarding?
None. What exactly do you think I went through?
One hears things. And given your history with the Americans, I expected them to want to get back at you.\nIt's good to hear that's not the case.
Are you going to stay with us or are you returning to the mainland?
I feel like it is expected of me to stay.
Hm, the duty to the motherland - a curse and a privilege at the same time. I know what you mean.\nThen I am glad we shall have more opportunities to meet.
I've heard you arrived recently.
Three months ago, in fact. I used to serve in Europe and Afghanistan.\nI was reassigned here to command the local air force when the previous commander retired.
I've flown in everything - helicopters, gunships, jets, gliders, even a hot balloon on one occasion.
Flying is in my blood passed through generations of pilots.
Do you perhaps wish to hear about my family history?
Why not.
Alright, sit down if you can, this is a long and epic tale about the Syomin pilot family.\nIt all started back in Imperial Russia, at the beginning of the century.
The aviation industry was just getting started. There was no air force to speak of just yet.\nScientists and engineers were developing some of the first aircraft designs.
It wasn't only planes at this point, but also aerostats, either airships or hot baloons.\nYou see, it had to start somewhere.
We were actually first in the aviation field to establish an aerodynamic institute.\nMy great-grandfather Nikita Syomin joined it and became an officer.
He was part of a scheme where several members of the office corps of the institute were sent to France to train on their aeroplanes.
He gained much needed experience and even found love - Marie Saugner-Syomin, my great-gradmother.
They eventually returned to Russia together and started a family.

At the outset of World War I, air force was strictly used for reconnaissance and coordination of artillery fire.\nLater, they were rearmed with steel flachettes and air-dropped bombs to attack ground targets.
You can imagine the effectiveness of those weapons.\nAfter some time, machine guns replaced them, which also enabled the aeroplanes to fight each other.
Nikita was never shot down, although he came close once, but managed to land successfully.
Nikita became an ace pilot and received the Order of the White Eagle and few other medals.
I still have them at my home, along with the other decorations and awards of my other family members.\nIf we ever get the chance, I can show you, if you'd like.
I already added a few to the collection myself.\nThe most successful is my grandfather, who fought in the Patriotic war.\nHe shot down the most enemy aircraft - incredible forty-seven!
But I digress, first there was the civil war.
The civil war is a somewhat dark passage in our family books - you see, Nikita actually fought for the Whites.
The war was bloody and hard. There was no joy in it, as Nikita used to say.\nIt was brother against brother. He was forced to shoot down many of his former colleagues and friends.
When it was finally over and the Whites lost, Nikita was pardoned. Possibly for his great skill and fame.
He left the army soon afterwards - he was unable to continue serving after such a horrendous war.\nIn his eyes, service lost meaning.
Now it is finally time for the greatest pilot in Syomin history, my grandfather, Aleksandr Syomin!
It was during the Great Patriotic War.\nAt the beginning, most of our aircraft got destroyed before they had a chance to take off.
Whatever was left was crambled and used to defend Moscow. Aleksandr flew air missions day and night, with little sleep and rest.
When the enemy finally retreated, he told me he slept for three days straight to recover!
Aleksandr was flying the famous Lavochkin La-5 model.\nIt was an incredible aeroplane.
With its revolutionary air-cooled engine and two cannons,\nit was powerful enough to challenge even the feared German Messerschmitt.
Aleksandr flew many sorties during the war and shot down by official accounts forty-seven enemy aircraft,\nthe most in our family history as well as sixth in total in all the Soviet Union.
He was made the Hero of the Soviet Union and received many medals.\nI added them at the lower shelf in our collection, right below my great-grandfather.
Each family generation has its own shelf, mine is the lowest.
My father and your namesake, Grigory Syomin, was more of an engineer than a pilot.
He worked in Mil - the aerospace manufacturer - and helped design and create most of their models.
He was also part of every test flight, so that still makes him parially pilot in my eyes.\nI am very proud of him, every time I fly in Mil model, I always think of him.
And not only him, actually.\nWhen I'm piloting, hundreds of meters above the ground, in a fight with enemy gunship, I remember all my forefathers.\nI'd like to think I'm making them proud.
So, there you have it,\nI told you about Nikita, the first pilot, Aleksandr, the best pilot, Grigory, the designer pilot, and Valentin, yours truly, the young pilot.
Thank you for listening to my family story, it's been a while since I told it to someone.
The pleasure is all mine.
You are very kind, comrade Lemontov. I knew I'd like you.
I'm sorry, perhaps another time?
No problem, comrade Lemontov.
I'm sorry, comrade Syomin, but can we get to other topics as well?
Of course, of course, we can return to this some other time.\nWhat else would you like to know about?
What can you tell me about the air force?
I command only handful of helicopters at the moment.\nTwo transport helicopters Mi-17 and one attack helicopter Mi-24.
I asked for at least one gunship in case of an emergency, but my request was denied.
There is a new design in the works, my father showed me.\nKamov V-80, I've only been able to see the blueprints, but it looks like it could rival the very best aircraft of the west.
I can't wait to get my hands on that, the production allegedly already started.
Thank you, comrade Syomin, it was nice talking to you. See you later.
I should be the one thanking, comrade Lemontov, for being such a keen listener. I'm glad you are back. Goodbye!
Likewise, comrade Lemontov. Goodbye!
Comrade Lemontov, do you wish to hear my family story again?
Is there something you wanted, comrade Lemontov?
If my eyes do not deceive me, I see comrade Lemontov. It's good to have you back, comrade.
Comrade Frolov, long time no see. How are you?
The same old, same old.\nI am still the commander of our armoured forces, though there are not really any forces to speak of.
I long for the old days. We waged a hard war, but it carried meaning.\nIt felt like we were achieving something, something nobody dared before us.
What happened with you after I was captured?
I was with comrade Volkov. We retreated with him to the mainland. Not everyone was so lucky, though.
When we got the island back, I returned here.\nNowadays, I hardly ever go back to the mainland. I like it here.
It's calm and quiet most of the time, though the weather got even more cold, if you can believe it!\nBut I am not giving up my sunglasses!
Because they bring you luck.
Your memory has no equal, Lemontov!
You said you don't go back home anymore?
Aye, I don't really have a reason to. My wife died five years ago. Cancer.
I'm sorry for your loss.
We lived separately the last few years, but it still hurt.\nWithout her, there is no reason to go back.
The last time I was in Russia, it was at her funeral. I never looked back ever since.
What's the current situation with the tanks?
We have hardly any, that's the main issue. Very little heavy tanks and modest amount of light tanks and transports.
We are able to support infantry to a limited extent, but in a tank battle we would not stand a chance.
We have been getting more stuff in lately, though we are still far away from a battle ready state.
What is the main tank model?
Still the good old T80 with slight modifications. There is no new design in the works anyway.\nYou can't improve what is already perfect.
Can't argue with that. Any new recruits?
A good amount. I train them personally.\nIt's a hard training, but if they can master the local terrain, they can fight anywhere.
Because of the treaty, they can't stay here, so we swap them around during the year.
It was good to see you again, comrade Frolov. Goodbye.
Likewise. Goodbye, comrade Lemontov.
Did you need something, cormade Lemontov?
The legendary Grigory Lemontov. Our paths have finally crossed. Captain Kaplinsky, at your service.
Greetings, comrade Kaplinsky. Are you the new commander of spetsnaz?
Yes, comrade Lemontov, but not for long now that you are here.\nWe're already getting you your uniform and equipment. You shall be back in the field in no time.
What do you have in mind?
You are probably a little rusted after seven years of prison.\nThe boys are ready to train with you and help you get back into shape.
Afterwards, we would like you to lead our spetsnaz forces again.\nYour skill and experience are unmatched and it is high time you put them to good use.
Your motherland needs you, comrade Lemontov, you should answer its call.
Playing on my patriotism, comrade Kaplinsky?
I consider us both patriots, comrade. We wouldn't be here otherwise.\nYou long to get back, I know it, because that's how I would feel if I were you.
What can you tell me about yourself?
I am really not that interesting.
I'd like to know who I'm going to be working with.
Hm, alright. I've been in spetsnaz for over six years.\nMy main areas of expertise are infiltration and sabotage.
I am proficient with rifles, small arms and most kinds of pistols.\nI am not bad with a sniper rifle, though I prefer to be a spotter.
I can keep my breath underwater for eight minutes and forty seconds.\nIt actually saved my life back in Afghanistan.
Our convoy was ambushed once.\nI was looking for survivors, but I could not find anyone still alive.
Suddenly, a large enemy patrol came upon me.\nI only had time to dash into a nearby bog and hide under the mud.
They were loud and probably drunk. I had to stay hidden as they were checking all the dead bodies, looking for supplies.
They spent painfully long time messing somewhere around me.\nI couldn't move, I couldn't breathe.
When my lungs hurt so much I thought they might burst,\ntheir voices finally grew quiet and I was able to get out of my hiding spot.
Never in my life felt breathing so hard and yet so heavenly.
In the end, I managed to find the convoy survivors, we ambushed that patrol and killed every last one of them.\nIt was very satisfying.
How are the spetsnaz?
We've got enough people to create one big group or two small ones.\nEveryone is quite experienced and versatile. I'm not worried about our capabilities.
If we are well supplied, we are a force to be reckoned with.
Thanks for the information. I guess we'll be working with each other soon enough.\nSee you later, comrade Kaplinsky.
I'm far from an ideal leader. I'll be glad to transfer my leadership duties to you.\nI'm looking forward to it, actually. Goodbye, comrade Lemontov.
I'm all ears, comrade Lemontov.
Excuse me, comrade, I'm looking for comrade Chernikov.
I believe he went to Chernoborg to check on supplies.\nYou should look for him there.
Comrade Lemontov? So it's true, you have been granted freedom?
Comrade Dostoevsky, it's been a while. Yes, I returned this morning.
That is very good to hear. The injustice of your imprisonment I could never comprehend.\nIt's another item to be added to the list of western hypocrisy.
I am glad you are back. The things are just not the same without you and comrade Livanokh.\nWe are now led by comrade Volkov, do you remember him?
Yes. What's he like?
He reminds me of comrade Livanokh.\nHe understands warfare as much as political issues and is able to manoeuvre in both spheres graciously and smoothly.
He takes good care of the army, even though the supplies are sometimes scarce, we are never left wanting.
And what about you?
I mostly train new recruits. Just recently, a new group arrived from the mainland.
They're greener than unripe apples at the moment, but once I am done with them,\nthey'll be able to charge across the battlefield while singing the Internationale in unison!
It's good to see you haven't changed, comrade.\nI'm actually looking for comrade Chernikov, he was supposed to be here.
Yes, he's been here recently. We had a small discussion, then he had to leave to check on some new shipment.\nHe went through that forest to reach the small port.
Did he go on foot?
He did, actually. You could say that he very much enjoys walking.\nYou should be able to catch up to him eventually! Good luck on your search, comrade Lemontov!
Thank you and goodbye, comrade Dostoevsky.
Comrade Chernikov I hope?
Indeed. You must be comrade Lemontov. It is good to see you alive and well.
You are not easy to find.
I'd like to keep an eye on things personally and that means I get around a lot.\nI am always reachable by the radio.
I haven't been given one yet. And I wanted to talk to you personally.
I am listening.
For how long have you been here?
For a year and a half. Before that, Europe.\nIn my line of work, you are usually not on the front lines, so I do not have any crazy stories to share with you.
Why did you leave Europe?
It was actually a hard decision, I very much enjoyed the nature and my day long hikes.\nBut then the demonstrations started and I didn't feel comfortable staying.
Did somebody get hurt?
I mean, we never fired any live ammunition, the police mostly deployed smoke and stun grenades.
The protests were kept at bay through non-lethal means, but I didn't stay after that.\nI just couldn't continue doing my work and pretending nothing happened, because it did.
There was a palpable tension in the air. I did not want to wait around till it gets bloody, so I left.
Since then, there haven't been any demonstrations of the same scale, but I think it's just a matter of time.\nAnd I'd rather wait out the storm here.
If you were ordered to shoot, would you?
That's a question I'd rather not know the answer to, comrade Lemontov.
What's the situation with supplies?
We are thousands of kilometers from the nearest port.\nIt takes shipments days and sometimes weeks to reach us and we can't use planes since we do not have an airport.
It improved slightly lately, but we must still be careful with what we have as replenishments take long time to reach us.
We do have enough to stay afloat, but I would like to get more.\nWe are currently in talks with the navy to get more supplies in from Vladivostok.
I must say, I would be overjoyed if it went through. The main concern is the treaty.\nIf the Americans see any more ships, they might go ballistic again and complain.
Our boys do deserve better. Last winter, we faced a serious lack of food and had to ration the little we had.\nI don't wish to repeat that ever again.
Thank you for your time, comrade Chernikov.\nI'll let you get back to your work. Take care.
No problem. I'll see you later, comrade Lemontov, goodbye.
Is something amiss, comrade Lemontov?
Postmaster Belsky?
In person. What can I do for you, comrade?
I'm looking for information about domestic politics and world affairs in the last seven years.
Hm, oddly specific, but I can certainly oblige. What do you wish to know about?
What's the situation back home?
Not good.\nThe economy is in recession, the political elite is corrupt and the socialist states and members of Warsaw pact\nare playing with the idea of secession.
What about the leadership?
There were many in charge in the last seven years.\nComrade Brezhnev died in 82, afterwards it was comrade Andropov,\nbut he only lasted until his untimely death in 84.
Then there was a troika of comrades Ustinov, Gromyko and Chernenko.\nComrade Ustinov died in 85 and was replaced by comrade Mazurov.\nThat's the current troika in power.
None of them have enough individual strength to rule alone and so they depend on each other.\nAt the same time, they try to weaken the others so that they can gain an absolute power.
The result is an ineffective rule and a lot squabbling.
I do not know how to fix the economy, but a draining war in Afghanistan and massive military spending do not help.
The seceding states is another matter.\nThere were few demonstrations already in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, the Baltic states...
The presence of the army restored order, but tension is in the air.
There will have to be a change in the next years, the situation is not maintainable.\nWhat this change is going to entail and whether it can be peaceful, I can't tell you.
One thing is certain - hard times are ahead.
How does the west look like?
The United States is as strong as ever.\nAlthough in recession for the first few years of the decade, now their economy is on sharp rise.
Ronald Reagan is the incumbent president since 81.
He took a hard stance against us - calling us an 'evil empire' and increasing the material support to our enemies.
They know we're in trouble and we cannot sustain the status quo for much longer.\nThey are going to win in the long run without firing a single shot.
I keep hearing about Afghanistan. The war there is still ongoing?
It was supposed to be a one year affair at the longest.\nNow it has become a seven year ordeal with no end in sight.

Although we captured all of the urban areas and the main roads, the mujahideen retreated to the mountains and waged a guerilla war.\nThey received substantial aid from abroad and the mountains provided them with cover.
We never managed to defeat them, it was impossible.\nEven leveling entire villages did not diminish them.
The war's been in a stalemate for years now.\nWe spent a lot to achieve very little.\n
I'm not sure what the current goal is, but even if we by some miracle managed to win, it would not have been worth it.
Thanks for all the information, I needed that.
No problem. Were you living under a rock for the past seven years of what?
You could say that. I just returned from captivity.
Wait, you are Grigory Lemontov. They told me you'd be returning today.\nIt was a pleasure, comrade! If you ever need any sort of information, I am your man!
That is good to know. Take care, comrade Belsky.
Goodbye, comrade Lemontov!
How can I help you, comrade Lemontov?
The hero has returned! I salute you, comrade Lemontov.
Comrade Kuznetsov, you haven't changed much. Still not an officer?
I am not suited to command people, comrade. I wouldn't take it seriously enough.\nI am much happier with my current position.
By your current position you mean the one you've kept for what, ten years?
My experience only makes me better. So I am both happy and good at my job, a win-win situation.\nDid you come to hear about what's been going on around here?
Precisely.
Then ask away.
Tell me about the end of the war, about the peace treaty.
After you were captured, they smashed the rest of our army.\nSome managed to retreat from the island, but many were taken prisoner.\nNot to mention all the equipment and vehicles.
In the end we managed to negotiate a somewhat favorable peace deal.\nWe had to renounce our claim on Everon and reduce the Kolguyev garrison to one hundred men.
In exchange, we received most of our prisoners back, with the exception of you. They also kept all of our equipment.
Everon was declared neutral and the Americans also left it and returned to Malden.\nThe peace treaty forbids us to come close to Everon and Malden, otherwise hostilities will resume.
And that is the status quo.
Tell me about Everon.
After the war, Everon regained its independence. They tried to establish a democracy, but it wasn't easy.
The rebel commander, Gaston Astier, had a sizeable following as well as number of armed men at his disposal.
The first few months, whatever the government decided, they had to check with Gaston first.\nIt felt like a military dictatorship in the making.
When Petain became president, he made a deal with Astier - he named him the commander of the militia,\ngranting him official power over the whole military -
- in exchange for not getting involved in the politics from there on.\nIt worked well for years.
Recently, there had been some trouble. The police chief, Daladier, will run for president in the next elections in a few months.
Petain is getting old and he might not get the support he once enjoyed.
If Daladier wins, Astier will not like it - he might get involved in politics again.
Police chief and militia commander - two armed institutions against each other - it might even boil over into a civil war.
The next presidential elections will be very interesting and their outcome might shape the future of Everon for years to come.
Do we know anything about Malden?
Still an American stronghold. It's their main training camp, heavily fortified and guarded.\nWe don't know much beyond that.
Thanks for the information, it was helpful.
No problem. Remember, you can always count on me! And let me tell you - I missed you! Goodbye, comrade Lemontov!
Take care, comrade Kuznetsov.
At your service, comrade Lemontov.
You're back. So, what do you think?
They're planning something. Possibly something big.

Supplies used to be scarce but things are to be improved significantly.\nMore tanks and helicopters are expected. A lot of new recruits are being trained here and in case of an attack they are at hand.
All of the commanders are experienced veteran soldiers.\nI wouldn't mind having them all in my command tent myself.
Well, except for Zubarev. He seems to be here as Volkov's yes man and political supporter.\nHe is in charge though, and must be taken into account.
They want me back to lead spetsnaz. My right hand is supposed to be Kaplinsky.\nA helping hand or a supervision? Hard to tell at the moment.
All in all, I feel like they're getting ready.\nIt might take months or even years, but something is going to happen eventually.\nIt does feel like Volkov is pursuing a plan.
Those are my thoughts as well. I'm glad we are on the same boat.\nWhat do you propose we should do next?
I'm not sure, actually.
What do you mean? Did you talk with everyone?
I did. I just didn't learn as much as I hoped.\nThe only thing I'm certain of is that they want me back to lead spetsnaz and that my right hand is supposed to be Kaplinsky.
Other than that, I don't know. It seems to me there are barely any soldiers or vehicles on this island.\nNot enough to mount an attack anyway.
At the moment, sure. But they are getting more. Like I said, they are slowly building up.\nTo what end I don't know, but I don't think we should just wait around to find out.
You're right, if Volkov is pursuing a plan, it is necessary to find out what that plan is.
My words exactly. What do you propose?
I'm going to talk to Volkov, first thing tomorrow morning.\nA general approach would be to get closer to them, gain their trust and eventually be invited into their plan.
A dangerous ploy. If it backfires, you might get killed.
A necessity. Since we do not know who else to trust, we need to infiltrate them to gain insight.\nOnly then we would be able to do more.
Volkov is going to ask you about Livanokh. What are you going to tell him?
Obviously not the truth, that's a possible death sentence.\nWhatever I tell him, hopefully it does not change his plans regarding me.
You are playing with fire, Grigory, but if you say this is the way to go, I shall support you henceforth.
Volkov is arriving in the morning, you should get some rest before that.\nI was told your equipment and uniform are ready in your tent, be sure to change.
I don't like the officer's garb anyway.
Have a good rest, Grigory, and good luck.
See you later, Stanislav.
That'll be all, thank you, comrade. Take care.
Comrade Lemontov, comrade Volkov has arrived and is waiting for you. Are you ready?
Yes, take me to him.
Comrade Grigory Lemontov, at last. We meet after seven long years and you look exactly the same as you used to.
Comrade Vladimir Volkov, time has been kind to me. You yourself have changed, though.
I'm not the person you remember, am I? Truly not. I have been busy the past seven years.
It took a lot of work and dedication to get where I am and it's only thanks to that you are now able to walk freely.
Do I owe my freedom to your high opinion of me?
Unfortunately, no, your exchange was much more pragmatic.\nI had to sacrifice valuable prisoners to get you out and that does not come cheap.
I'm hoping you feel at least some level of gratitude, enough for you to be willing to join me and my cause.
I got a feeling that whatever I feel is inconsequential.
It would be better if you agree willingly.\nI do not wish to force you, comrade Lemontov, for the old time's sake if nothing else, but I will.
I did not free you to simply let you go.
All you had to do was ask.
Good. I see you've gotten your uniform already.\nYou shall lead spetsnaz again with comrade Kaplinsky as your right hand and comrade Zubarev as your commanding officer.
I'll leave you some time for training and getting back into shape and afterwards,\nwe shall begin working towards a better future.
But before that, there is one last thing we need to discuss. You surely have expected it.
I don't like going back to it.
I know it's not easy, but I need to know.\nIs there anything you should tell me about the day comrade Livanokh died and you were taken prisoner?
I have to lie, otherwise I'm dead.
It's blurry, comrade Volkov. I remember we wanted to set a trap for Dyaconsen, the American spetsnaz.
To this day I'm not sure what exactly happened, but our plan backfired.
I remember standing above comrade Livanokh's body, my hands bloody. No breath, no pulse, he quickly grew cold.
Upon realizing he was dead, it was like my soul left my body and I stood there paralyzed.\nI could not come to terms with the fact that he was gone, forever.
Part of me died that day in the villa. I don't know how it happened and most likely I never will.
I only know that I failed comrade Livanokh the moment he most needed me.
I understand, comrade Lemontov. Do not worry, comrade Livanokh will be avenged. I'll make sure of it.
I'm officially restoring your rank of major and granting you your old position of commander of spetsnaz.\nYou are now once again part of the Red Army.
Forgive me if I don't involve you in my plans for now.\nYou have been away for a long time and I need to make sure I can fully trust you first.
Do not worry, we shall achieve great things together very soon.
Welcome home, comrade Grigory Lemontov.
Welcome home, Grigory.
I talked with everyone important. I can return to Shaposhnikov in Severovodsk.
Ny spetsnaz clothes and sniper rifle, finally.\nNow to get some rest and survive the meeting with Volkov.
I'm busy, Grigory. Come back when you talked with everyone.
A map of Everon. They're keeping a close eye on the island.
The ports used to be full of ships...
The only heavy tanks I came across...
There are less people here...
Old models, though reliable...
The spetsnaz base... the elite soldiers...
Comrade Lemontov, welcome back!
We salute you, comrade!
All hail comrade Lemontov!
Follow the officer

There are five commanders you have to meet with as well as two optional meetings with soldier from logistics and postmaster.
